item.title: From Adjoint Operator to Singular Value Decomposition
item.description: Isometry A linear map is isometry if it perserves norms. interesting properties: Isometry $\ S$ times its adjoint $S^{* }$ equal identity $I$ $$S^{*}S = I$$ Orthonormal basis will be staying orthonormal to each others $$Se_1, … , Se_n$$ Unitary Operators An operator $S \in \mathcal L (V)$ is called unitary if is an invertible isometry interesting properties: Isometry $S$ times its adjoint $S^{* }$ equal identity $I $, and it has communitativity $$S^{* }S = SS^{* } = I $$ $S$ is invertible and $S^{-1}=S^{*}$ $S$ is a unitary operator $\iff$ $\ S^{* }$ is a unitary operator Suppose $\lambda$ is an eigenvalue of a unitary operator.
